content.statement: aku-001-composite-number-definition is a fundamental concept in Science Math Number-Theory Composite-Numbers that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding aku-001-composite-number-definition helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of aku-001-composite-number-definition include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of aku-001-composite-number-definition.

definitions_glossary.divisor: A number that divides another number evenly without remainder
definitions_glossary.proper_divisor: A divisor of n that is not n itself
definitions_glossary.prime_number: A natural number > 1 with exactly two divisors
definitions_glossary.factorization: Expressing a number as a product of other numbers
definitions_glossary.prime_factorization: Expressing a number as a product of prime numbers

properties: Every composite number has a unique prime factorization
Composite numbers become more frequent as numbers grow larger
Most natural numbers are composite (infinitely many exist)

tests.name: trial_division
tests.description: Test divisibility by integers from 2 to √n

tests.name: primality_test_negation
tests.description: If a number is not prime, it is composite

definition.@value: A positive integer greater than 1 that has at least one positive divisor other than 1 and itself

prerequisites.title: Natural Numbers
prerequisites.reason: Must understand natural numbers to define composites

prerequisites.title: Multiplication
prerequisites.reason: Composites are products of smaller numbers

enables.title: Prime Factorization
enables.reason: Every composite has a unique prime factorization

enables.title: Divisor Theory
enables.reason: Understanding composites enables study of divisor functions

related.relationship: Primes and composites partition natural numbers > 1
Fundamental Theorem guarantees unique prime factorization
Difficulty of factoring large composites secures RSA

skos:related.skos:note: Complement to composite numbers in natural numbers > 1

learning_objectives: Distinguish between prime and composite numbers
Identify composite numbers by finding factors
Understand that 1 is neither prime nor composite
Recognize composites as products of primes
common_errors: Thinking all even numbers except 2 are composite (TRUE, but often stated as misconception)
Believing small composites are easy to factor (generally true, but not always)
teaching_tips: Use factor trees to visualize composite structure
Compare and contrast with prime numbers
Show that most numbers are composite
Use visual arrays (e.g., 12 dots arranged as 3×4)
